newsitem.title: USA: Netscape, IBM plan browser for OS/2.
newsitem.headline: Netscape, IBM plan browser for OS/2.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp and International Business Machines Corp said Wednesday they will develop a version of Netscape's popular Navigator Web browser for IBM's new OS/2 Warp 4 operating system software.
The version of Navigator, which will recognize speech, should be available for testing in September and for end users in 1996's fourth quarter, Netscape said.
IBM plans to launch OS/2 Warp 4, the latest version of its personal computer operating system, in September.
The version of Netscape Navigator that will be the browser for OS/2 is Navigator 2.02. IBM and Netscape also said that Netscape's next version of Navigator, code-named Galileo.

"IBM and Netscape are natural partners, given both of our commitments to open standards like Java and HTML," Bob Lisbonne, vice president of client product marketing at Netscape, said on a conference call. He was referring to two widely used languages for Internet application development.
IBM said the deal confirms its commitment to OS/2, which has long been an underdog of operating systems with a small share of the PC market, versus Microsoft's.

"It is our sincere hope that this announcement today will go a long way to doing that (demonstrating OS/2 commitment)," said Walley Casey, vice president of client product management at IBM, in response to a question on the conference call.
"This company remains firmly behind OS/2," Casey said.

OS/2 Warp currently has over 14 million users. Analysts said that while the move to make Netscape the primary Web browser on OS/2 Warp is a positive one, it will not likely lead to a huge surge of new users of OS/2.
